External context.description: Uncaptured data provided by the self-tracker to understand and explain a phenomenon shown in the data
example_quotes: I think that was soon after my surgery and that maybe would make sense cause I’d have to get up to take medicine and maybe being restless or something.
So for the most part…I mean, this graph is informative in that it doesn't usually take me long to fall asleep. So this is confirming what I already know about.
That was the opposite of what I was expecting. I would've expected that as I ate healthier I would've been burning more calories.

Identify value.description: Explicitly specify the measured value, its range for one or more clearly identified data points, or the difference between two measured values
example_quotes: And it looks like my highest since I've started using it is 7,958. I wonder what date that was.

Identify extreme.description: Explicitly state the identities of the data points possessing extreme values of the measure variable
example_quotes: Yeah, look at this peak. 11/2014 that was a trip to San Francisco.

Identify references.description: Explicitly state the values of categorical variables, labels from the axes, or legends
example_quotes: It says I'm taking a lot of weekend steps. That's quite surprising.

By time segmentation.description: Compare measured values segmented by time
example_quotes: I could see every month this year I'm improving.

Multiple services.description: Compare the same data type from two or more services
example_quotes: Yeah, so the—yeah, definitely interesting to see that the two devices gave very different trends.

Against external data.description: Bringing in external data for comparison
example_quotes: I have data for the same period for my HDL and my LDL and my triglycerides. My weight is important but those are just as important as well as to how those values are changing.

By factor.description: Compare measured values by a factor (other than time)
example_quotes: What was happening in February 2015? [Laughter] I bet I can tell you what those are. That's one of my son's sleep regressions.
The plan says no exercise after 7:30. And these two data points is basically validating that you've got to stick by it.
Then there’s also a time when I had surgery actually both holidays. In 2013 I had shoulder surgery in December. Everything went down.

Value judgement.description: Convey positive or negative connotations about the data
example_quotes: It’s pretty irregular. I really wish I woke up at the same time. This is really bad.

Variability.description: Explicitly state the variability of measured values
example_quotes: This is around—around here is when my son was born. Second kid. So, you know, some of this stuff—you can see trending up as you're not taking care of yourself. Son gets a little older, things go back to normal.

By category.description: Explicitly describe the variation of measured values across all or most of the values of a categorical variable

Correlation.description: Specify the direct relationship between two variables (but not as comparison)
example_quotes: So the Calorie data matches the Steps data.

Outlier.description: Explicitly point out outliers or state the effect of outliers
example_quotes: The min and max are interesting. But from a global perspective, they're probably outliers on asleep.

Data summary.description: Summary of collected data (such as number of data points, duration of tracking, and averages)
example_quotes: So about two years, and averaging over ten [10,000 steps]. My goal is set at ten [10,000 steps], so that makes me happy.

Prediction.description: Predict the future based on the collected data
example_quotes: Yeah, Martin Luther King. So if I go to comparison of weekend I think my weekends tend to be sluggish. Weekdays are okay.
